content: The Act titled "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" addresses the interstate transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste under the Solid Waste Disposal Act. A new section, SEC. 4011, is added to regulate this aspect. The Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act prohibits out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal without local government authorization. The Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act requires authorization from local government for disposal or incineration of out-of-state municipal solid waste. Authorization must be granted formally, recorded in writing, and is final. Prior to granting authorization for out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal, local government must formally approve it at a meeting, record the decision, and ensure it is final. The government must also request specific information from the facility owner or operator seeking authorization. The local government must require specific information from the facility owner seeking authorization for out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal, including a brief description of the facility and anticipated waste quantities. The facility owner must provide a brief description of the facility, including size, waste capacity, and anticipated monthly and yearly waste quantities for inspection by the Governor, local government, Indian tribe, and other interested parties. The facility owner must provide a description of the facility, waste capacity, and anticipated waste quantities. This includes volume of waste for existing facility and any planned expansion, along with a map showing site location, road system, topography, and buffer zones. The facility owner must provide a map of the facility site showing its location in relation to the local road system, topography, and hydrogeological features. The map should also indicate any buffer zones to be acquired and all facility units, along with a description of the environmental characteristics of the site, including information on ground water resources. Definitions for this section are provided. The Administrator acknowledges a State's exemption from section requirements upon notification. Definitions include "affected local government" as officials with primary jurisdiction over a landfill or incinerator site. The term 'affected local government' refers to elected officials with primary jurisdiction over a landfill or incinerator site, while 'affected local solid waste planning unit' refers to a political subdivision with authority over solid waste management planning. 'Host agreement' is defined as an agreement related to the facility. The term 'host agreement' is a legally binding agreement between a landfill or incinerator operator and a local government allowing the facility to accept waste from outside its jurisdiction. A host agreement is a legally binding contract between a landfill or incinerator operator and a local government, allowing the facility to accept municipal solid waste from areas outside the local government's jurisdiction.
